Okay Religion is often very close to people's hearts, and so it is a touchy subject. If you are going to post here, please be objective and respectful. I'm not interested in heated, empty comments posted to insult or to anger, but I'm perfectly happy to calmly discuss differences.
 
 I grew up in the Bible belt, where I often was told that I believed some or all of the following:
 1: Human sacrifice
 2: Virgin prisoners in our temples
 3: Oxen worship
 4: Devil worship
 5: Animal Sacrifice
 6: God had sexual relations with Mary
 7: Polygamy
 9: Adam (as in Adam and Eve,) is God
 10: Cannibalism
 11: The Great God Mormon or The Great God Joseph Smith
 
 And so very many other amusing things. Many people have written things about us that are completely fabricated and many people have believed them. None of the above things are remotely true. 
 
 If any of you have heard weird things about us and would like to know if they are true, or even based on the truth, or just have questions, then feel free to ask. We do believe some things that many people think are weird. 
 
 I'll be posting accurate versions of the more commonly distorted doctrines from time to time. The first is this:
 
 MORMON.
 He was a man, mortal as you or me. We believe that God has reached out through prophets to all of his children, not just the ones in Mesopotamia/Mediterranean area. We don't claim to have all the writings of all the prophets (Even many non-mormon scriptural scholars agree that several writings that are mentioned in the bible that are missing,) but we do believe that we have some from the ancient inhabitants of the American Continents. This would be the Book of Mormon, so called because of the prophet Mormon, who collected these writings into one volume. We don't worship Mormon any more than any other Christian worships Moses or Matthew. 
 
 We do also believe in the Bible, and see the Book of Mormon as assisting it, not detracting from it. The Book of Mormon is subtitled, "Another Testament of Jesus Christ," and we see it as such. It reads much like the new testament, with sermons on faith, and urging us all to love one another, and to come unto Christ, in whom we may be saved.
 
 We believe that God lead a more modern prophet named Joseph Smith to find this book, and he translated it. We don't worship him, ether. We respect him as being a great man, and that's all. 
 
 Okay, I'm way tired and need to go to bed now. If anybody is curious enough to care, I'll check this thread tomorrow and answer your questions.

 The bolded is news to me since I lived in Salt Lake City for nearly a decade and made some very good LDS friends there. I was always told that the Tablets were obviously sacred objects and therefore kept in a very well hidden and protected place within the Temple where only the Prophet and Elders still had access to them. Exactly where is this hill called Cumorah located? It isn't that bunker they have built into the wall about a mile up the road at the base of Little Cottonwood Canyon, is it?

Esdraelon, once again, I see where you are coming from. 
 
 THE PLAIN FACTS:
 Polygamy, or the practice of having more than one wife was indeed practiced by the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day saints, for several decades. What I was referring to in my list is the current practice. I have had numerous people attempt to convince me that polygamy is a current lifestyle practiced by my religion. This is false. It was discontinued over a century ago in compliance with US law. Official Declaration 1 This is a link to an official LDS declaration that affirms the discontinuance of the practice. 
 
 HOW/WHY IT STOPPED:
 The following link is the "Articles of Faith," 13 points of our basic doctrines. 
 Articles of Faith 1
 #12 refers to our beliefs in complying with law. Regardless, most of the reasons that polygamy was implemented were by that time no longer existent. I'll touch on that more in a minute.
 
 WHY PEOPLE THINK WE STILL PRACTICE POLYGAMY:
 There are many fringe groups claiming to be "Mormon" that still practice polygamy. I assure you that they are not. Any person practicing polygamy is excommunicated from our church. Notwithstanding that, I can't tell you how many people ask me, "How many wives does your dad have?" To which I would reply, "Seven. How many does your dad have?" And then I'd enjoy their expression for a second, before telling them the truth, that any true LDS will have only one spouse. I admit, I love messing with people. I know, I really shouldn't... 
 
 WHY WE EVER DID:
 This is tricky to answer in any way that be relevant to any that are not of my faith. There are many reasons that have been claimed by LDS and non LDS alike. Some are true, some have elements of truth, some are merely possibilities and some are complete fabrications.
 The first reason is simply that we believe that it was the will of the God. We believe that we are lead by living prophets, and as Amos 3:7 says, God reveals His will through prophets. 
 There are reasons that can be more universally understood, if not necessarily accepted. The LDS church was heavily persecuted at the time. For example, Missouri had an extermination order out for Mormons. Any Mormon had to leave the state, abandoning their property with no compensation, or be killed. Many of our men were killed in attempting to protect their family and property. Very few of our women were killed. Beyond this, there were more female converts to our church than male, leaving a heavy gender imbalance. As you may know, in the the 1840's, women led a very different life. Society was set up for men, making it hard for a women to earn a living or own property. This is even more true of the widow with small children. How will she take care of a family? Marriage was a lot more important in those days. So several women were married to one man.
 Even at it's peak, polygamy was very limited, never being practiced by more than 3% of the LDS population. Even then, it wasn't a volunteer system. Men were called to it specifically, typically ones who could afford to provide for more than one family. Many of the plural wives were never sexual partners of their husbands; but they were provided for by the husband. These plural wives always had to give their consent, and were never forced into such arrangements. 
 After several decades of this practice, the US law came down forbidding plural marriage, and we stopped the practice. By that time it wasn't needed anyway. The US government wished for all of the plural marriages performed before the law was enacted to be nulled. We agreed to not perform any more marriages, but many of the men refused to divorce their plural wives, leaving them unsupported. They served their time.
 
 Some offer the explanation that our polygamist practices were simply the ultra-conservative following of the Bible, Exodus 21:10, Abraham and Jacob (Israel,) being several examples. I think this may have been part of it, but I give more weight to the material circumstances of the time. 
 
 Any questions? I'm thinking next time I'll post some theories that American historians have postulated as to why we had such troubles in that era, and specifically in Missouri.

ROMEBIGRED: Since you brushed aside my original point of 'eternal progression,' please explain this below:

 It is very important to know the specific context, because we hold a prophet to speak the words of God only when he is speaking as a prophet; in other words, in a General Conference meeting, Special Assembly, or when he specifies that he has received a revelation. Outside these circumstances, he is a regular man, speaking his own feelings. We do not hold regular men as infallible.These are, I would like to point out, not canonized volumes of church doctrine. They are secondary sources; no original has been verified. They do not represent the views or doctrine of the church. I do not believe them, nor are they principles taught among the believers. The principles that are cannon are that Christ and God are our only judges, and that Christ, not Joseph Smith, is our mediator with the Father. 
 
 Here is a doctrinal quote from Joseph Smith
 "The fundamental principles of our religion are the testimony of the Apostles and Prophets, concerning Jesus Christ, that He died, was buried, and rose again the third day, and ascended into heaven; and all other things which pertain to our religion are only appendages to it." 
 
 Even the cover of the Book of Mormon states "Another Testament of Jesus Christ." Even everything we do in the temple is centered around Christ. He was the only perfect man, and the only name by which we can be saved.

I know first hand the political clout the Mormon Church enjoys there, and wields when it serves their purpose. If the LDS Church really wanted polygamy wiped out in Utah, it would have been wiped out a century ago.
 They follow a different leader, not our prophet, and have occasionally forced marriages between cousins, and under-aged cousins at that. If you knew as much as you claim about my religion, you would know that having fundamentalist radicals who create no end of bad press, and call themselves "Mormon" on national TV is undesirable. They are no friends of ours, and do us no favors. We have no reason to do them any favors. 
 
 Given what you say your "LDS" friends told you, I am beginning to doubt the validity of your claim be a Utahn and to know things about my religion...
 
 
There's a reason why they own both Newspapers in Salt Lake City. And they have influence at every level of state government. 
 They own one, and both run stories from time to time showing the church in a negative light. They are run independently. 
 
 This is quite the conspiracy theory you are working on here...
 
 
And you must or should also know that Utah remained a territory and was denied statehood for decades until she would finally agree to outlaw polygamy. In other words she did it very begrudgingly in order to gain the benefits of statehood. 
 As I said, it was practiced for decades. Polygamy was not outlawed in Utah when it was a territory, that it true. However, if it was only to receive the benefits of statehood, then one might ask why we didn't give in decades before? Believe as you like. Choose your own reasons. 
 
 
So your matter of fact statements which paint the church in the most innocent and upright light leaves much to be desired.
 As do yours to paint us as the most disgusting lecherous lumps to ever defile the earth. I admit, wrongs have been done on all sides. As i like to say so often, "God had a perfect church, until he let people into it." Even Christ had a Judas. No organization deserves to be judged because of the bad apples. 
 
 
And I realize that we haven't really gotten into the meat of the doctrinal failures the church follows which are in direct conflict with the holy bible, and that includes the book of Mormon which is extra biblical material which has no place in any spiritual discussion. The question is, can you defend your religion using only the bible, apart from the book of Mormon? 
 Yes I can. I don't believe us to be in contradiction with the bible at all. 
 
 
And do the mormon doctrines conflict with Gods word as interpreted by the rest of main line protestantism? The answer to that question is most assuredly YES.
 This is true, some LDS doctrines do. Yet, for me, that is hardly a deal-breaker. That's like a Hindu warning you that your beliefs are not in keeping with the Upanishad. If I believed that the Protestants were right, I would be Protestant. However, there are many religions recognized as Christian which are not Protestant. Protestants believe in Christ, but are not the only Christians.

I still have a life outside this forum. I would like to ask that you hold off the questions and posts for tomorrow so that I have a chance to respond to what has already been asked/claimed/whatever.
 
 I am going to use only the Bible as scriptural text in this part. I am used to defending my faith using only the Bible, and used to the fact that many view the bible as violating the commandment to not add or take away from. ( Yes, we believe the Book of Mormon doesn't violate that. I'll come to "why" later.)
 
 Briefly, we believe in a far more actual sense than most Christians that we are created in God's image. (And yes, that means we believe differently than the Protestants.) We believe we are His children. 
 
 Easyrider, your question is about to be answered. We believe that God organized our spirits from pre-existing "intelligences." The word that is translated in the KJV as "created" and "formed" is "baurau." (I'm unsure of the spelling.) This can mean "organized" with the connotation of pre-existing matter. In some versions of the Bible, it has been translated in that way. Christ was the first and greatest of us to be born from intelligence to spirit, and is the Firstborn of God. He is greater than any of us, and has always been. His intelligence, or consciousness, was never created. His essence is eternal. 
 
 We believe that we are in the complete image of God, and are very much the children of God. As such, there is a spark of the divine in all of us. We believe that we are to worship God, but that is not the sole destiny that He has in mind for all of us. We believe that as a Father who loves His children more than anything else, He wants more for us, and has a plan for us to be able to progress to our full potential.
 
 What is that potential as children of God? Romans 8:17 "And if children, then heirs; heirs of God, and joint-heirs with Christ; if so be that we suffer with him, that we may be also glorified together." What is an heir? Like an heir to a kingdom? One who inherits. We are joint-heirs with Christ, what does that mean? A joint-heir is a co-heir, and heir that shares in the inheritance. What did Christ inherit? How will we be "Glorified together?"
 
 Speaking of Christ, Philipians 2: 6 says, "Who, being in the form of God, thought it not robbery to be equal with God:" This was His inheritance.
 
 Philipians 3: 21, "Who shall change our vile body, that it may be fashioned like unto his glorious body, according to the working whereby he is able even to subdue all things unto himself." Christ has a perfect body, the body of a God. An omipotent body.
 
 As to the couplet, "As man is, God once was; as God is, man may become," we believe this to be supported by John 5:19, "Then answered Jesus and said unto them, Verily, verily, I say unto you, The Son can do nothing of himself, but what he seeth the Father do: for what things soever he doeth, these also doeth the Son likewise." The Son took on flesh, lead a mortal life. Then, afterward, as we read in Philipians 3: 21, He received a perfect body, and was raised to a higher state. 
 
 Therefore, yes we believe that God also has a body, and that he also followed the pattern of Eternal Progression. We also believe it because he formed us in His own Image. Like I said, we believe that a bit more literally than the Protestants. He is perfect in knowledge and power, and progresses only in kingdoms and dominions. All our glory adds to His.
 
 One final scripture; Matthew 5:48 "Be ye therefore perfect, even as your Father which is in heaven is perfect." How is he perfect? He is perfect in love, in knowledge, in power, in form, and in action. He exhorts us to follow Him in that. 
 
 Having said the above, I know that many are riled, and consider this the most atrocious, self-elevating blasphemy that they have ever heard. I understand. I was shocked at first, too. It may help to know that we believe that we will ALWAYS be subject to God. According to us, He will ALWAYS be our Father, and ALWAYS be greater than us. Our glory only adds to His, so the greater we become, the more honor and glory to the Most High. It may not help much, but...
 
 It may help more to point out that there are several accepted branches of Christianity that believe a similar thing, except that they believe we are all parts of God Himself, and merge back into Him after death.
 
 We also believe that we can never do this on our own. As many of you are saying to yourselves, "We could NEVER be worthy of that!" And we agree. By ourselves we will never measure up. It is only through the grace of God, and the sacrifice that Christ made for all of us that we may be cleansed. 
 
 Seriously, the reason the Esdraelon brought this up is that it is the most divergent belief that we have. After polygamy and Eternal Progression, we are fairly standard Christians.
 
 The reason I said that we had strange beliefs, but regular practices is this exact thing: really, what does that change in trying to live as a disciple of Christ? Christ is still our only hope, our only salvation. He is still far beyond us, and more perfect than we could ever hope to be. God is still our Father. We still must live as best we can on this earth. 
 
 It changes doctrine, but not practice. Faith is necessary for salvation. According to James 2:18, "Yea, a man may say, Thou hast faith, and I have works: shew me thy faith without thy works, and I will shew thee my faith by my works." What we practice is our faith. 
 
 I am not trying to convince anybody that they must believe as I believe. I'm not asking or expecting you to accept it. Don't interpret it to be that way. I am merely stating what we believe, and why we believe it. I know that it is contrary to many of your beliefs, but I ask you to please be respectful in your replies.

So... I spent more than an hour on a very detailed response. Then somebody tripped over my computer chord, bringing it crashing to the floor, and shutting it off. I had most of it saved, so I'll just post that, and go to bed. If there are parts that don't make sense, or are incomplete, I'll correct them tomorrow.
 
 
Another item we need to understand at the start is that Article 8 of the Mormon Articles of Faith (Note 2) says, "We believe the Bible to be the word of God as far as it has been translated correctly." (Italics mine.) This approach allows Mormons to ignore key Bible Scriptures which refute Mormon doctrines. 
 For the record, in such discussions, I never use the Joseph Smith Translation. I use the King James Version. I do this so that it's obvious that I don't use it as an easy out. None of the scriptures I quoted are JST, they are all KJV. Yet the Bible contradicts itself, by telling us in one story of Paul's vision of Christ on the road to Damascus that Paul's companions saw the light, but heard not the voice, yet in the other tell us that Paul's companions heard the voice, but saw not the light. 
 
 Yet again when we read 
 John 1: 18 No man hath seen God at any time; the only begotten Son, which is in the bosom of the Father, he hath declared him.
 1 Jn. 4: 12 No man hath bseen God at any time. If we love one another, God dwelleth in us, and his love is perfected in us.
 
 Yet this is contradicted again in the following:
 
 Acts 7:55 But he, being full of the Holy Ghost, looked up stedfastly into heaven, and saw the glory of God, and Jesus estanding on the fright hand of God,
 
 Exodus 33: 11 And the Lord spake unto Moses face to face, as a man speaketh unto his friend.
 
 Ezekiel 1:28 As the appearance of the bow that is in the cloud in the day of rain, so was the appearance of the brightness round about. This was the appearance of the likeness of the glory of the Lord. And when I saw it, I fell upon my face, and I heard a voice of one that spake.
 
 Genesis 32:30 And Jacob called the name of the place Peniel: for I have seen God face to face, and my life is preserved.
 
 These and many other such examples are used by anti-Christians to discredit the Bible.
 
 With so many differing translations, (List of English Bible translations - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia) it is impossible to believe them all of equal truth, especially when they contradict each other on occasion. I once had a Jehova's Witness tell me that all versions of the Bible are equally correct. Using his version, which is very different that the one the King James Version that I use, all of his arguments made sense. Using the KJV, they didn't. To me there seems some discrepancy then, in the assumption that every translation is equally correct. Also, I am fluent in Italian, and have read the Diodati version of the bible extensively, and large portions of a couple of others. I have read the New World translation in English. There are several differences in the wording, that significantly add to or change the meaning. For instance, the KJV notes that "The Lord sent an evil spirit between Saul and David," and then Saul threw a javelin at David in an attempt to kill him. Why would the Lord do that? In the Diodati, it just states, "Venni un spirito malvaggio," or "There came an evil spirit between Sual and David."
 
 We do believe the Bible to be the word of God. "as far as it is translated correctly," just means that we do not believe every translation is correct. Given your clear opposition to the "Joseph Smith Translation," it seems that you agree with us. You believe the Bible to be the word of God, "As far as it is translated correctly."
 
 Incidentally, Joseph Smith (who was fully fluent in more than six languages at the time of his death; learning them in the pursuit of reading as many different translations of the Bible as he could,) said that after the JST, the German Bible was more correct a translation than any other.
 
 
In general, Mormons, and I say again, this is not my first ball, will use the Holy Bible to 'defend their faith' as long as it suits them to do so, and as long as they can pull out of 'context' that which suits their purpose.
 "as long as it suits them". Nice wording there. Yes, it "suits" me whenever I speak about religion. I submit that it suits you too. Please start. And about "out of context"...
 
If we are to continue this, we will need to agree on the meaning of 'context'. Context, unfortunately, is many times relative to the person reading the passage or whatever he is reading. Context is very convenient in dodging the essence of a question. 'Context' in scripture is, in my opinion, that accepted by a wide range of different biblical theologians in agreement, similar to the way the books in the bible were studied and deemed 'scriptural'. Although we also have our own view of a passage based upon how the spirit moves us, too often we are moved much by our own prejudices and pre-determined perceptions rather than what the spirit is actually trying to tell us. 
 I agree fully with the part in the italics that I added. As to the rest, I propose that we use the internationally accepted definition of the word "context." (Context - Definition and More from the Free Merriam-Webster Dictionary) Namely, "the parts of a discourse that surround a word or passage and can throw light on its meaning." I understand this to mean that a thing is out of context if removing it from that context changes its meaning. I am interested to know how you feel that the scriptures I quoted are "out of context." In your interpretation, how is the meaning changed? In what way would the meaning be affected when placed back in context?
 
 If I am using these or any other scriptures that I have quoted out of context, then please tell me how, in specifics. This is all my own research, so there may be mistakes. In these instances I am confidant that I have not made any mistakes, but I would like to better understand your opinion. If it will help, I can at least give backgrounds for each verse that I cite. I just assumed that you had a Bible, and would look up the context.
 
 In case anybody doesn't have a copy of the Bible; and would like to read the context for themselves, here is a link to a copy of the scriptures, including the King James Version of the Bible. (This is the official site of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. The Joseph Smith Translation is contained in the footnotes only, but is there in case you are interested to know what it contains.) Scriptures
 
 
 
Bible verses used to counter Mormon teachings are brushed off in favor of passages from the Book of Mormon and other Mormon scriptures (as well as ongoing revelation that often contradicts previous LDS Church teachings).
 If we felt that the Bible and Book of Mormon contradicted each other, then we would not believe in both. I certainly do not "brush off" Biblical verses in favor of Book of Mormon text. Some LDS who are less familiar with the Bible than the Book of Mormon may do that, but I am actually more familiar with the Bible. 
 
 
It should be noted that the LDS Church has published its own version of the King James Bible, incorporating footnotes explaining what corrections from Joseph Smith's "inspired version" of the Bible (a version full of errors and plagiarized material) should be taken into account
. Yes, we do have an LDS-specific translation, and are hardly the only religion to have a self-sponsored translation, but ...Plagiarized? Where exactly? And as far as errors, I will consider that a matter of opinion until a third-party linguistics expert is able to prove to me the errors. I am fairly proficient in Latin (after learning Italian, it was a short jump.) and my father is fluent in Hebrew, having worked with the government in Jerusalem. A close friend of mine in Italy was Greek. They all say that the majority of the JST (Joseph Smith Translation) alterations are readily justifiable. Admittedly, I have no source for the Aramaic texts, and none of them hold degrees in linguistics. Regardless, I have yet to be convinced that the JST is so flawed.

 First of all, I want to thank you for you direct manner, and for asking such excellent questions. These do have a big impact on the way that we view the nature of the Godhead, or Trinity; and are therefore important.
 
 To understand our beliefs here, we must begin with the fact that LDS are non-trinitarian. We believe in God, the Father, in His Son, Jesus Christ, and in the Holy Ghost, but we believe them to all be separate beings. We are a minority among Christians, in that; but there are several that agree with us, such as Pentecostals. (Nontrinitarianism - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia) There are many scriptures that can be interpreted to give strong backing to the concept of the Trinity. Non-Trinitarians interpret them differently. 
 (This rest is speaking only for LDS, not other Non-Trinitarians.) For example, Christ says that He is one with the Father in John 17:21 "That they all may be one; as thou, Father, art in me, and I in thee, that they also may be one in us." John 17 He is praying for the Apostles and their converts. We believe that He is saying that He wants them to be one with Him and each other, etc, in the same way that He is one with the Father. We believe that this means in purpose, action, and thought. As we understand it, if this were not so, then He would be asking the Father to invite the Apostles and their converts to merge into one being and merge with Him and the Father; an invitation to the Godhead. (As context, Christ is kneeling with His Apostles, offering the Intercessory Prayer, and is praying specifically for "the men which thou gavest me out of the world:"--verse 6--We believe that He is praying for His Apostles and all of their converts: "also which shall believe on me through their word") Having said this, I can definitely see how you it can be interpreted differently. I think that honestly, to a third party, the scriptures that are cited in support of one or the other are equally convincing, which mean it comes down to personal conscience, hearing the Holy Spirit, and personal faith.
 
 Therefore, if God created all things, (except that we believe that Christ created the earth at His commandment,) and God is not the same thing as Christ, then it makes sense God created Christs' spirit. 
 
 
1. When did this birth from intelligence to spirit occur? Are you talking about way before Jesus' incarnation on earth?
 
 
 Yes. It happened before your or my creation, before the creation of the world, but there is a caveat to that... We believe that to God, time is non-linear. We believe that time is measured only unto man, and that to God, all times are the present. This makes it a tricky question... However, in time as we understand it, Christ was first. (The Pearl of Great Price Student Manual, Religion 327 © 2000 by Intellectual Reserve, Inc.)
 
 
2. And what existed first, the intelligence from which the Spirit of Christ was supposedly born, or Christ from which intelligence originated?
 They are the same. "intelligence" as used in LDS spiritual context, is not "smarts," it is essence of being, personality, and self. It is eternal, and therefore, Christ, as a being, as a personality, as an entity, has always existed. It has many meanings, but in this context, these are the meanings. 
 
 
3. Was Jesus always God, or did he become God at some point? Please be specific.
 Excellent questions! I have actually never been asked this one before, which, for the number of these discussions that I have been involved in, is saying something. Our doctrine does not specify whether He was God as an "intelligence", but it never intimates that He wasn't. As a spirit, in His earthly life, and afterward, Christ is most definitely God.
 
 Truth be told, these is what we LDS lovingly refer to as "space doctrine." That is; it is information that does not affect daily practice of our religion. It is not a doctrine that you will hear every Sunday in church. It is still important, but not as important as the concept of faith on Jesus Christ as our Savior, God and friend, or of God as our Father, all of which affect our practice daily.
 
 I know that some portions of this, or all of this, are seen as heretical by many or perhaps all who believe in the Trinity. What I state here is not intended to convince you to change your beliefs, but merely stating what ours are. Regardless, thank you for your patience and for the respectful way that you asked those questions.

Esdraelon, You have given me excellent, substantiated and specific posts to reply to, thank you. This will have to be my last post today, I'm neglecting my classwork. I ask that you withhold any further claims until I have time to respond to what you have already posted. I will cover the claimed contradictions in my next post.
 
 Briefly, as far as Historical claims, I think that this argument is dead in the water. We are talking of a matter of personal faith, and faith often seems to stand at odds with material evidence. One can argue that the evidences support us as well as counter us, like so:
 
 Historically: 
 When the Book of Mormon was published, many laughed at it from a historical aspect. They claimed that there were no civilizations in the ancient American continents that were so advanced and developed by 600 BC. Since then, ruins have been discovered that pre-date the previously known ones ones by several thousand years, with conclusive evidence of expansive trade. This gives us a possibility of a civilization as developed and as ancient as the Book of Mormon says. [url=http://bruceowen.com/worldprehist/3250s17.htm[/url] The Olmecs were up and at 'em even before 600 BC.
 
 Likewise with cement. It was claimed that there was no cement in the ancient American continents. The Book of Mormon says there was. Ancient cement has since been discovered. (David S. Hyman, A Study of the Calcareous Cements in Prehispanic Mesoamerican Building Construction [Baltimore: Johns Hopkins University, 1970], pp. ii, 6-7)
 
 Ditto horses in the Book of Mormon. It was claimed there were no horses in pre-Columbian Americas: Clayton E. Ray, "Pre-Columbian Horses from Yucatan," Journal of Mammalology 38 (1957): 278 
 and
 Carl Chapman, "Horse Bones in an Ancient Indian Mound," Missouri Archaeologist 7, no. 1 (April 1941): 3-8.
 
 And science:
 We follow a health code that we call the Word of Wisdom. Declared in 1833, it requires us to not drink alcohol, tea, or coffee. Tobacco was also prohibited in all forms except as a medical wrap. In the time it was released, this was laughable. Smoking was thought to aid digestion. Nearly a hundred years later, science caught up with this teaching. (Greaves, Lorraine (2002) High Culture: Reflections on Addiction and Modernity. edited by Anna Alexander and Mark S. Roberts. State University of New York Pres) 
 
 (FARMS is an organization interested in proving the historical evidences of the Book of Mormon, (http://maxwellinstitute.byu.edu/) and is composed of members of the LDS church. They have found many secularly accepted archeological links that they insist support the Book of Mormon. Feel free to browse for yourself. NOTE: the results of FARMS do not represent the views of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.)
 
 All I'm saying is that such arguments bother me. They go back and forth and back and forth with proof upon proof. Sometimes one side (LDS, or non-LDS) will "prove" something, then a few years later, that "proof" is discredited. (Once again, LDS and non-LDS alike.)
 
 As to the DNA, I will not pretend that there is a specific empirical rebuttal for that. (although I have not been able to find the text of that study to be able to verify that it is as conclusive as claimed. I would appreciate any help in finding it.) Just as science "proved" that smoking aided digestion, (see above citation,) and turned out to be in error, as well as the claim of the absence of cement, and the horse, I submit that this may prove that way as well. Science also "proved" cold fusion. This is not the first time that we have claimed something that seemed to fly in the face of evidence. We are not afraid to do so, and as the posts above show. Regardless, for me the empirical evidence for LDS is just as strong for it as it is against. We have already been proven right in some instances. If our belief were founded on one DNA study, and not on Christ, we may have been shaken; yet our membership hasn't even dipped in the light of this study. As it is, a DNA study cannot controvert for me the witness of the Holy Ghost. Scientific theories come and go, but a witness of the Holy Ghost is constant.
 
 Perhaps we are, as you say, selective in the evidences that we accept. We prefer the evidences we feel in our hearts from (as we believe) the Holy Ghost. To some degree, aren't we all that way, as believers?
 
 Many Christians feel that evolution contradicts Adam and Eve, yet the seeming evidence for evolution continues to mount. 
 
 Many Christians believe the history of the earth (or mankind in some beliefs,) is seven thousand years from start to finish, yet archeologists continue to disagree.
 
 Dinosaurs were also thought to eliminate the "Garden of Eden," and the age of the earth. 
 
 Consider, if you will, how crazy it must have sounded to claim that a man had risen from the dead? Science cannot support that.
 
 Ask any avid atheist to tell you how he feels Christians deny science and history. He will have an arsenal. How is this different?
 
 Personally, I am unsure as to why so many are so very eager to prove us right or wrong. We are less than 0.5% of the world's population. Many of the rest of the population does not accept Christ. There is war, hatred, and need nearly everywhere; and so many people have nothing better to do than to tear apart somebody's religion, or to prove something that can only truly be known as a matter of faith, not of tangible evidences. (in my mind, FARMS is guilty of this too...) 
 
 I weary of your mentality, which seems to me to be that this is a fight, to be won or lost. I am not interested in attack or defense. Admittedly, I created this thread on a "debate" forum, and you have every right to post so very aggressively. However, I meant this more as an explanation of our actual beliefs, because I found them misrepresented in such threads as this one: http://www.4forums.com/political/religion-debates/13865-did-god-have-sex-mary.html I meant merely to set forth what we believe in question and answer to posts like Easy's. Obviously, my beliefs are not acceptable to all, and heretical to many. Likewise many of your beliefs in my eyes. I think we all knew this to begin with. You have said this is not your first such discussion, and if that is true, then surely you have found what I did; that such discussions often become heated, and leave each side exhausted, angry and frustrated, but not convinced. I am willing to respond to your myriad of posts and claims, but keep in mind that I am not interested in converting, but in eliminating ignorance. Converting or convincing is not my job, it is the job of the Holy Ghost. Faith is a personal connection to and belief in God, and not the result of debate. I have never seen much of a point in what we LDS call "bashing", or religious "proof" debates. 
 
 Anyhow, I find the historical and scientific evidences interesting, but do not base my faith on them. 
 
 See you tomorrow.

I have to go to work in a minute (as always, just a quick one...) Esdraelon, I'm jealous of how much time you have! Or how quick your fingers are. 
 
 
BoM: 1) ". . . for we know that it is by grace that we are saved, after all we can do." (Book of Mormon / 2 Nephi 25:23)
 Holy Bible: For by grace are ye saved through faith; and that not of yourselves: it is the gift of God: not of works, lest any man should boast. (Ephesians 2: 8,9 - true faith will have works (cf. James 2:17) but faith alone saves.)
 (bold, italics mine) Agreed! As a matter of fact, we completely agree with you as shown by the very scripture that you quoted. Please note the bolded, italicized word "grace". In full context, this scripture explains that even if we do all we can, we are still unworthy of heaven. We cannot ever hope to simply work our own way to heaven. Therefore, it is "by grace that we are saved." One may vary well paraphrase like so "Even all we can do is not enough, so it is still only because of the grace of God that we are saved." We emphasize the need for Christ; not supplant it. 
 
 We most certainly agree that faith saves, which faith is incomplete without works, just like James says, but is still what saves. Nothing more. 
 
 
BoM: 2) . . I remembered also to have heard my father prophesy unto the people concerning the coming of one Jesus Christ, a Son of God, to atone for the sins of the world." (Book of Mormon / Alma 36:17) (Italics mine)
 
 Notice that it says "a Son of God." Jesus is the Son of God, not just a Son of God. 
 1 John 4:15 tells us, "Whosoever shalt confess that Jesus is the Son of God, God dwelleth in him, and he in God.
 Please note the entire wording here. "one Jesus Christ, a Son of God," (italics added.) Surely you can't be serious in suggesting that we believe in many Jesus Christs? This passage is like me saying your post was from a certain Esraelon, in response to one romebigred. How many romebigreds are there to choose from on this forum? How many Esdraelons? Just one, or we wouldn't have been able to have registered these names. We wholeheartedly believe that Christ is the Only Begotten, the only Son of God. 
 
 
3) "And behold, he shall be born of Mary, at Jerusalem which is the land of our forefathers, . . ." (Alma 7: 10)
 But Jesus was born in "Bethlehem of Judaea" (Matthew 2:1 - cf. Luke 2:4 & Micah 5:2). Jerusalem is a distinct city and not "the land of our forefathers." Furthermore, Jesus was born in Bethlehem which is a distinct town outside of Jerusalem (Emmaus and Bethany are closer to Jerusalem. He was not born in the district of Jerusalem but in the district of Judaea.
 This is in the Book of Mormon, about 500 years after the first writers left Jerusalem. Nephi (the first writer in the Book of Mormon,) refers to it correctly. He once lived there. By Alma, the usage had evolved. Jerusalem was 500 years ago, and across an ocean. No maps remained, no contact was maintained. Jerusalem became a term used among this people to describe that whole region. In this instance, they were spoken to in terms that they understood. The names "Bethlahem" and "Judea" would mean nothing to them. 
 
 One of the only books that Joseph Smith had ever read at the time he translated the Book of Mormon was the Bible. I submit that even if he were making up the Book of Mormon, he had read the Bible too many times to become confused on such a basic and well-known point.
 
 That's all I have time for right now... I am eager to answer your other points. Hopefully this afternoon? I'm not sure. I have three mid-terms this week.

post_info.post_title: Quick post--Sorry I didn't post yesterday.

Once again, I just have a minute. Esdraelon, I thank you for this portion of your post: 
I will quote your response above later, but let me make a few points to ease your mind.
 I am generally aggressive in a debate forum, however, I am not out to 'win' or 'lose' or show you up.
 It is not my intention to judge as you are free to believe what you like and your salvation is your own. The only thing I would tell you to be careful of is not to cause your brother/sister to stumble. 
 This does indeed ease my mind. I find it odd that so many are quick to condemn me with venomous words when they find out that I am LDS. Not all of them, by any means; I have many very dear friends who are Baptist, Catholic, Evangelist, Assembly of God, non-denominational, Jewish, even Muslim and Buddhist. Anyhow, rest assured that I would never do anything to knowingly cause my brother or sister to stumble. What I do is what I am convinced is the right thing to do. I have a W.W.J.D. bracelet; a gift from a dear Baptist friend of mine. I wear it daily, and try to live by it the best that I can.
 
 
The Christian world by and large appears to hold your church as a cult, thus one would assume that there is grounds for doing such. 
 Yeah, this one confuses me. I think it to be most likely a misunderstanding of definition. (Cult - Definition and More from the Free Merriam-Webster Dictionary) A cult is any religion. "2 A system of religious beliefs and ritual; also : its body of adherents" Catholics actually use it to describe various movements within their own church, such as the Franciscans. Definition 3 may shed more light: "3 : a religion regarded as unorthodox or spurious; also : its body of adherents" We are certainly unorthodox; we have many different beliefs from the majority of Christianity, even if we share many of the same practices. Whether we are spurious is debatable. The phrase "a cult" is often confused with "occult." The literal definition is this: "to shut off from view or exposure" (Occult - Definition and More from the Free Merriam-Webster Dictionary) Our temple worship may be seen to fit this description. We keep it to ourselves with the belief they are sacred, and that it may only be spoken of within the walls of the holy temple. HOWEVER: the common use of both "a cult" and "occult" have much more commonly understood connotations, including devil worship, fundamentalist radical activism (often violent), witchcraft, brainwashing, and manipulation. None of these apply, and therefore I have never understood the claim that we are a cult or occult in this context. 
 
 
There is a huge recovery umbrella on the web for former Mormons and Mormons wanting to leave the church, etc. Why is this?
 
 
That may be the case, but again, I don't see many former Christians in need for counseling the way it appears the Mormons' do, but maybe I am mistaken.
 I have many good friends who were once Mormon, and are no longer. I would put a rough estimate at about 50 that I have known. Of those, I maintain close contact with maybe 25-30. None of them described deep trauma; and none are in therapy. I would need more information as to what the nature of their counseling is; what the specifics of the difficulties are, and whether they are actually "Mormon," or belong to a previously mentioned fundamentalist splinter group which purport to be "Mormon," but have no affiliation. I would expect people from Warren Jeff's compound to need therapy, but I would not consider them to be Mormon.
 
 Here's the next part that I wanted to respond to:
 
 
1. If Gods are individuals who have passed through mortality and have progressed to Godhood, how has one person of the Trinity (the Holy Spirit) attained Godhood without getting a body? (See Acts 5:3,4) Some Mormons say ya'll believe this Trinity? Is this true?

 
 God is more than just those who have passed through mortality, and have progressed. It is a being which deserves our worship. We are non-trinitarian. We believe that The Holy Ghost, Heavenly Father, and Jesus Christ are all God, but are separate beings. This does not mean that they do not deserve our worship. We do believe in the Holy Spirit as a spirit.
 
 
2. If Gods are individuals who have passed through an earth life to attain Godhood, how is it that one person of the Trinity (Jesus Christ) was God before He received a body or passed through earth life? (Matt. 1:23 and Hebrews 10:5) Easy asked something very similar.
 See the above. 
 
 
3. If the Book of Mormon really contains the fullness of the Gospel, why does it not teach the doctrine of “eternal progression”? (See D&C 20:8,9) 
 An easily understood misinterpretation of the word "fullness". Going back to where I said that the doctrine of Eternal progression was not something that influenced our daily practice, I was referring to the fact that it is not a "saving doctrine." That is, it is not something that need  be known or believed to achieve salvation, or heaven. The "fullness" of the Gospel are the "saving doctrines;" the things relevant to how we live and what is necessary to know, understand, and believe. These are the things that pertain to Christ, his Sacrifice, the Holy Spirit and the witness of Christ that it gives, along with charity for all men, and how to strengthen ourselves against the temptations of the devil. The Book of Mormon focuses on those things. 
 
 According to Joseph Smith, the Book of Mormon is only about 1/3 of the golden tablets. (Therefore he couldn't have claimed that there was nothing more to be known; just that all that was  necessary to know was there.) He was forbidden to translate the rest at that time. The reason was given that once we lived by what we had, and fully used it, we would get more. I don't think any Christian can say that Christians in general live by the Bible as much as they need to, and so it is with us.
 
 Thank you again for the quality of these last posts, and your patience that I can't respond to them all at once.
 Got to get to class again, see you soon.

What a busy week! I'm currently sitting in class, but I have another 10 minutes before it starts. 
 
 Response to Esdraelon's excellent post, part III:
 
 
1) "For I know that God is not a partial God, neither a changeable being; but 
 he is unchangeable from all eternity to all eternity." (Moroni 8:18)

 
 This is most certainly true, as the Bible verifies multiple times. This is a very well-known point.
 
 
About 14 years after the 1830 Book of Mormon came out, Joseph Smith refuted his own book! In a major sermon (see Teachings of the Prophet Joseph Smith, compiled by Joseph Fielding Smith, p. 345) we read:
 "We have imagined and supposed that God was God from all eternity. I will refute that idea, and take away the veil ..."
 Now we come to the point where we discuss "eternity" and "time". It is a commonly accepted point that, "Time is measured only unto man." In our doctrines, time works very differently for God than it does for us. One common way to put it is that all time is the present to Him. Given the theory of relativity, even physicists admit the theoretical possibility of such a thing. This makes the question, "Was God always God?" a sticky one. Yes, He always is and always has been, but given our linear mortal view of time, it is next to impossible for us to fully comprehend. (but physicists are on their way to it!) 
 
 As an aside, I can understand why you would feel this to be a contradiction, just like I feel like the following excerpt from the Nicean Creed describing the Trinity to be self-contradicting; " Now the Catholic Faith is this: that we worship one God in Trinity, and Trinity in Unity. Neither confounding the Persons, nor dividing the substance. For there is one person of the Father, another of the Son, and another of the Holy Ghost. But the Godhead of the Father, of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost is all one, the glory equal, the majesty co-eternal. For such as the Father is, such is the Son, and such is the Holy Ghost. The Father uncreate, the Son uncreate, the Holy Ghost uncreate; the Father incomprehensible, the Son incomprehensible, and the Holy Ghost incomprehensible; the Father eternal, the Son eternal, the Holy Ghost eternal. And yet, there are not three eternals, but one eternal. As also there are not three uncreated, nor three incomprehensibles; but one uncreated, and one incomprehensible..." and it goes on for several more such statements. (Creeds of the Catholic Church) 
 
 This confuses me further when understood from the context of John 17:3. "And this is life eternal, that they might know thee the only true God, and Jesus Christ, whom thou hast sent." As I asked a seminarian in the Vatican who was a year away from becoming a catholic priests (after 7 years of school,) if we could ever come to know God, according to the Catholic interpretation, he responded that God was The Father Incomprehensible, and therefore we could not. I do not know what the Protestant interpretation is, but this view still has me confused.
 
 
2) "Behold, David and Solomon truly had many wives and concubines, which thing was abominable before me, saith the Lord." (Jacob 2:24)
 Perhaps Joseph had forgotten all about Jacob 2:24 when he had this 'revelation' recorded in Doctrine & Covenants 132: 1:
 ". . . I, the Lord, justified my servants Abraham, Issac, and Jacob, as also Moses, David and Solomon, my servants, as touching the principle and doctrine of their having many wives and concubines- "
 We hold that polygamy is only permitted when God gives His specific approval, as shown by the fact that polygamy among early LDS was selected and not volunteer-oriented. It may be that God had not given His approval to these marriages; BUT far more specifically, it is what is written in Kings itself. 
 s
 The following verses are from First Kings 11: 1 But king Solomon loved many strange women, together with the daughter of Pharaoh, women of the Moabites, Ammonites, Edomites, Zidonians, and Hittites;
 2 Of the nations concerning which the Lord said unto the children of Israel, Ye shall not go in to them, neither shall they come in unto you: for surely they will turn away your heart after their gods: Solomon clave unto these in love.
   
 4 For it came to pass, when Solomon was old, that his wives turned away his heart after other gods: and his heart was not perfect with the Lord his God, as was the heart of David his father.
 5 For Solomon went after Ashtoreth the goddess of the Zidonians, and after Milcom the abomination of the Ammonites.
 6 And Solomon did evil in the sight of the Lord, band went not fully after the Lord, as did David his father.
 7 Then did Solomon build an high place for Chemosh, the abomination of Moab, in the hill that is before Jerusalem, and for Molech, the abomination of the children of Ammon.
   
 9 ¶ And the Lord was angry with Solomon, because his heart was turned from the Lordds God of Israel, which had appeared unto him twice,
   
 11 Wherefore the Lord said unto Solomon, Forasmuch as this is done of thee, and thou hast not kept my covenant and my statutes, which I have commanded thee, I will surely rend the kingdom from thee, and will give it to thy servant." 1 Kings 11 It seems pretty clear to me that God did not approve of these marriages which tore Solomon from the worship of the true God. The Jews had been commanded to marry only amongst their own specifically for this reason. Solomon disobeyed God's commandments of marriage.
 
 This next one I already covered, really... "One" in a figurative sense, like Mark 10:8 "And they twain shall be one flesh: so then they are no more twain, but one flesh." LDS believe the Nicean interpretation of "One" to be an overly literal interpretation.
 
3) ". . . And now, behold, this is the doctrine of Christ, and the only and true doctrine of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost, which is one God, without end. Amen." (2 Nephi 31:21) 
 'I will preach on the plurality of Gods. I have selected this text for that express purpose. I wish to declare I have always and in all congregations when I have preached on the subject of the Deity, it has been the plurality of Gods. ... I have always declared God to be a distinct personage, Jesus Christ a separate and distinct personage from God the Father, and that the Holy Ghost was a distinct personage and a Spirit: and, these three constitute three distinct personages and three Gods. ... we have three Gods anyhow, and they are plural; and who can contradict it?" (as recorded in Teachings of the Prophet Joseph Smith, p. 370)
 
 Who can contradict it? Well, consider 2 Nephi 31:21, Alma 11: 44, Mosiah 15:1-5, and "The Testimony of Three Witnesses" at the front of the B.O.M. (not to mention D. & C. 20:28)!
 (Bold added) As I said before, and cited biblical scripture to do it, we believe that they act as one. In various contexts, the word God has many different connotations in LDS scripture. There are false gods spoken of, God as in our Heavenly Father, God as in part of the Godhead (Father, Son and Holy Ghost), and God as a divine race. The reason that we still consider ourselves monotheists is because we believe that Christ said to the Father, "Father, thy will be done, and the glory be thine forever." Reference Search: Moses 4:2 This is to mean that He would serve God, but that He would not take Heavenly Father's place as our God. (meaning the Father that we pray to, and the one we hope to return to in heaven.) 
 
 In many of our scriptures, it is not specified whether Christ or God the Father is speaking to us. This because it does not matter to us whose voice it is, because they all act as One. God the Father commands, and Christ and the Holy Spirit serve Him perfectly as He commands. Therefore their work is God's work, therefore we claim that they are one God. 
 
 I hope this makes our belief somewhat clearer.

"plainess of the gospel" (I Ne. 13:24)
 VS.
 "fulness of the gospel."
 
 "white and delightsome people" (2 Ne. 30:6)
 VS.
 "pure and delightsome people"
 
 Why the change from white (skin-color) to pure (moral quality)? Probably this tampering with the text (which was faithful to the 1830 ed.) was an effort to remove a source of irritation for dark-skinned people.
 Plainess to fullness and white to pure is not changing the meaning. In the 1800's at the time of the publication of the BoM, "Plainess" was used synonymously with "fullness". "The plain truth" was full and unadorned. We do not have such a succinct phrase today, but "fullness" was considered to be the closest approximation.
 
 "white" to "pure" is a much more well-known one. Even to the 1930's, "white" was used as "pure" or "good". when somebody did something nice for another, "that's awfully white of you," was a common reply. White was clean, without faults. "Pure as driven snow" is a phrase you might have heard. Why is snow considered so pure, when there must inherently be an impurity (dust particle, etc.) for the H20 molecule to stick to in order for an ice crystal to form? Why say it is pure? Because it is white. It was not referring to skin color, but to cleanliness. Dirt is far more evident on white linen than any other color. Nowdays, that usage has racial connotations, and is no longer so common. 
 
 As to the "battle in New York", this is mistaking the hill Cumorah for the Battle of Cumorah. Moroni, the last writer in the BoM buried the plates in the hill Cumorah, and named it Cumorah after the name of the battle that was the end of his people. It was not the same place. Moroni wrote that he had wandered for 20 years after the destruction of his people. (Mormon 8) This was 20 years before he ended his account.
 
 Regardless, as my history professor says, "The bulk of what we know is nothing compared to the bulk of what we don't." He compares archeology to an alien lowering a net down in a city, and coming up with a dog, a street sign and a few cigarette butts, and trying to piece together what happened. Even if we had claimed that this battle took place in upstate New York (far from the city), how much of upstate New York has been excavated in search of this battleground? Now, given the understanding that we believe that this happened in South America or Central America, and distant from their cities... This leaves a lot of area uncovered to search for a 1400-year-old battleground. (Reference Search: Mormon 6:1-4)
